overview: From 2025-10-12 to 2025-10-19, ethereum-optimism/op-geth had 4 new PRs (4 merged), 0 new issues, and 35 active contributors.

topPRs.title: all: Make DA footprint gas scalar configurable
topPRs.author: joshklop

topPRs.title: Calldata footprint block limit spike
topPRs.author: sebastianst
topPRs.body:
**Description**

Spike of calldata footprint block limit implementation.

Following the idea of [multidimenstional gas metering](https://ethresear.ch/t/a-practical-proposal-for-multidimensional-gas-metering/22668) (but without changing regular gas accounting), a new _calldata footprint_ resource is introduced. The calldata footprint is of the same scale as transaction gas. The total calldata footprint of a block is limited by the same gas limit as for regular gas. This has the effect that total calldata usage of a block is constrained, with the right parameters, more than by calldata (floor) gas usage. The _calldata footprint cost_ is comparable to the regular _calldata floor cost_, but higher values would be chosen.

Using the FastLZ-based estimated size of a transaction from Fjord, a transaction's calldata footprint is now simply `calldataFootprint = estimatedSize * calldataFootprintCost`. So it estimates the transaction's calldata impact on the DA batch it will be a part of, scaled to be comparable to gas, so it can be limited by the same block limit.

A block's _gas used_ field is now set to the maximum of the two resources, the total gas used of all transaction (as before), and the total calldata footprint of all transactions. This has the benefit that the EIP-1559 fee market now also takes total calldata footprint into account and the base fee reacts to calldata-heavy blocks.

An open question is whether we want to make the _calldata footprint cost_ a protocol constant, or configurable per chain via the `SystemConfig` L1 contract.

**Tests**

<!--
Please describe any tests you've added. If you've added no tests, or left important behavior untested, please explain why not.
-->

**Additional context**

<!--
Add any other context about the problem you're solving.
-->

**Metadata**

<!-- 
Include a link to any github issues that this may close in the following form:
- Fixes #[Link to Issue]
-->

topPRs.title: core/types: Implement Jovian Operator Fee Fix
topPRs.author: fakedev9999
topPRs.body:
This is a consensus breaking change.

**Description**

Updates operator fee formula to be more useful.

**Tests**

Updated `TestNewOperatorCostFunc` and `TestTotalRollupCostFunc`.

**Additional context**

- https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/16623
- https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs/pull/299

**Metadata**

- Closes https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/17002.

completedItems.title: consensus/beacon: Fix OP Legacy header verification dispatch
completedItems.body:
**Description**

Fixes header verification to correctly dispatch to OP legacy pseudo consensus only for OP legacy headers.

**Test**

Did a successful snap-sync test of op-mainnet and op-sepolia, which performs full header chain verif

completedItems.title: all: Make DA footprint gas scalar configurable

topContributors.summary: maurelian: Focused on improving test infrastructure and enhancing security features within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They merged a refactor of test initialization contracts in PR #17889 and proposed new security features to restrict transaction scheduling to Safe owners in open PRs #17883 and #17900. Additionally, maurelian was highly engaged in supporting the team's work, providing 18 code reviews this week.

scharissis: Focused on improving the stability of the `op-acceptance-tests` suite in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, merging seven pull requests to address flaky tests. Their most impactful changes included simplifying test logic by removing 63 lines of filtering code in PR #17891 and migrating notifications to Slack in PR #17843. This work, supplemented by five code reviews, shows a clear emphasis on improving test reliability and fixing bugs within test and configuration files.

geoknee: This week, geoknee focused on the Jovian upgrade, implementing a key bugfix for operator fees in `op-geth#696`. They supported this core logic change by adding a new failure mode analysis in `design-docs#347` and creating six new issues to track further testing and enhancements. Their activity shows a balanced focus across bugfixes, documentation, and tests, complemented by providing 11 code reviews across the project.

bitwiseguy: Focused on improving the reliability and test coverage of the `op-deployer` in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, landing three PRs to address this. Their most significant contribution was adding extensive CLI tests (#17849), alongside fixing an artifact URL bug (#17848) and re-enabling an upgrade test (#17852). This work, combined with 11 code reviews, demonstrates a primary focus on test enhancements and bug fixes.

sebastianst: Focused on consensus mechanisms and the Data Availability (DA) footprint limit, merging a fix for legacy header verification in `op-geth` (op-geth#697) and updating the DA footprint limit specifications (specs#800). In addition to opening issues to track further implementation of the DA footprint limit, they were highly engaged in collaboration, providing 17 code reviews. Their work was split between bug fixes and other feature development, touching both core code and tests.

ajsutton: This week, ajsutton focused on improving the reliability of the dispute monitoring system, merging a bugfix to correctly handle out-of-sync nodes in `op-dispute-mon` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17831). They proactively identified further areas for improvement by opening three related issues and were highly engaged in team collaboration, providing 15 code reviews. Their work shows a primary focus on bugfixes and tests, particularly within test and configuration files.

pcw109550: Focused on enhancing the robustness of acceptance tests within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They made a significant contribution by adding a comprehensive new test suite for reorg and gap-filling scenarios in PR #17893 (+521 lines), and also improved test reliability by adding retry logic in PR #17894. This work was split between tests and other related code changes.

Inphi: This week, Inphi focused on improving testing and deployment infrastructure, merging an integration test for the `op-deployer` in ethereum-optimism/optimism#17865. They also began work on updating the upgrade method for `disputegame-v2` (optimism#17874) and actively supported the team by providing 11 code reviews. Their contributions show a primary focus on a mix of general development, bug fixes, and testing.

devin-ai-integration: Focused on improving test quality and organization within the ethereum-optimism/optimism repository. They merged two refactoring pull requests to improve test organization and coverage, including #17896 for SafeSend and #17839 for ReinitializableBase. With five additional open PRs targeting similar test enhancements and 14 comments on pull requests, their work was centered on improving the project's test suite.

smartcontracts: Focused on operational improvements and testing efficiency for the Superchain and Optimism, merging three PRs this week. They added validation instructions for `op-txverify` (ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops#1251) and optimized fuzz testing runs (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17877). In addition to this work, they were an active collaborator, providing 9 code reviews.

axelKingsley: Focused on preparing the `op-supernode` component for its initial release, merging PRs to set its v0.1.0 version and Docker target (#17906) and to update its documentation (#17878). They also began new work on the `op-conductor` component by opening a feature PR (#17880) and a related issue for improvements (#17879). Throughout the week, they were an active collaborator, providing 9 review comments across the repository.

AmadiMichael: Focused on a significant refactoring and bug-fixing effort, committing +7983/-8838 lines of changes and opening PR `ethereum-optimism/optimism#17902` to remove an input from the superchain upgrade process. In addition to this development, they were highly engaged in collaboration, providing 16 code reviews. This work was primarily concentrated in test and configuration files.

mds1: Focused on supporting the team through extensive code review this week, providing feedback across 20 pull requests. Their efforts resulted in 8 approvals, helping to unblock teammates and move work forward.

aliersh: This week, aliersh focused on improving the AI contracts testing infrastructure within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They merged a key feature to add Slack notifications and bug fixes (PR #17876), and also resolved artifact exclusion failures in the test suite (PR #17840). Their work was concentrated on bug fixes and tests, primarily modifying test and configuration files.

bradleycamacho: Focused on a major information architecture restructure within the `ethereum-optimism/docs` repository. This work resulted in two open pull requests (#1791, #1792) proposing a significant overhaul, reflected in the modification of 263 documentation files with over 7,100 lines added and 7,800 removed.

yashvardhan-kukreja: Focused on coordinating infrastructure readiness and upgrades within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They drove this effort by creating 11 issues to track the Fusaka readiness for Flashblocks components (#17853), upgrade rbuilder (#17854), and manage sequencer configurations (#17682), closing 9 of these tasks. In addition to this project management, they supported the team's work by providing 9 code reviews.
Vaios0x: This week, Vaios0x's efforts were directed toward the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, where they opened two pull requests for review (#17845, #17844).

joshklop: Made significant progress on client stability and testing within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, authoring substantial code changes (+3398/-896 lines). They opened two pull requests to improve beacon client robustness (#17866) and align mock behavior (#17881), and also merged a devstack improvement in PR #17904. This activity shows a primary focus on new development, testing, and bug fixes.

MSilb7: This week, MSilb7 focused on the `op-analytics` repository, landing a significant modification to revenue wallets in PR #1754 (+808/-87 lines). They also shipped a fix for collective balances in PR #1755. Their contributions were a mix of bug fixes and other changes, with a quarter of the modified files being for configuration.

mbaxter: Focused on collaboration and improving code quality this week, providing extensive feedback through 9 code reviews. They also helped define upcoming work by creating an issue to track the implementation of the v2 dispute game in OPCM.deploy (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17257).

JosepBove: Focused on new feature development, opening a pull request to add IERC165 support on SaferSafes (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17864) which modified 21 files. They also supported the team by conducting 3 code reviews. The work this week shows a focus on bugfixes, with significant changes to test and configuration files.

opgitgovernance: Focused on improving test stability by merging a significant refactor in the acceptance tests for `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (PR #17851). This large-scale change (+2520/-4145 lines) aimed to reduce test flakiness, an effort they are continuing with two other open PRs on the same topic. Their work, which included 8 PR comments, was entirely concentrated on the project's test suite.

janjakubnanista: Focused on operational improvements and CI stability this week, merging a pull request to improve CI error messages in ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry#1118. They also identified and created two on-call issues to address CI failures (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17754) and enable log retention (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17859). This work was supplemented by 3 code reviews, with their overall code contributions reflecting a focus on bug fixes and other operational tasks.

jelias2 contributed a fix to the `ethereum-optimism/infra` repository, correcting a typo when adding a new member via PR #492. They also supported the team by reviewing three pull requests and commenting on an issue.
almanax-ai: Participated in code reviews this week, leaving 8 comments on pull requests.
